docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 1 PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO THE SUPREME COURT ONLY [rr 40.1 –40.4]

heading.title: PART 40 ADDITIONAL MEASURES FOR ENFORCING JUDGMENTS AND ORDERS OF THE SUPREME COURT AND DISTRICT COURT [rr 40.1 –40.8]
DIVISION 1 PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO THE SUPREME COURT ONLY [rr 40.1 –40.4]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 40 ADDITIONAL MEASURES FOR ENFORCING JUDGMENTS AND ORDERS OF THE SUPREME COURT AND DISTRICT COURT [rr 40.1 –40.8]

leg:heading.title: ADDITIONAL MEASURES FOR ENFORCING JUDGMENTS AND ORDERS OF THE SUPREME COURT AND DISTRICT COURT [rr 40.1 –40.8]

entry.emph: Division 1 — Provisions applicable only to the Supreme Court Rules 40.1–40.4

row.entry: This Division provides an additional mode of execution (sequestration) for money judgments in the Supreme Court.

entry.emph: Division 2 — Provisions applicable to the Supreme Court, Land and Environment Court and District Court — Rules 40.5–40.8

row.entry: This Division provides for committal as a mode of execution for certain judgments in the Supreme, the Land and Environment Court and District Court.

Rules 40.1–40.4 only apply to proceedings in the Supreme Court. Rules 40.5–40.8 apply to the Supreme, the Land and Environment Court and District Court. None of the rules in this Part apply to proceedings in the Dust Diseases Tribunal or the Local Court: see r 1.5 and Sch 1.
The rule is based on various provisions of the former SCR — including Part 42 rr 2, 6, 8 and 9; Part 44 r 3 and Part 53 r 6.
Committal of directors of a corporation — enforcement against ‥ [40.6.10]
Effect of the writ of sequestration ‥ [40.3.15]
Judgment altering entitlement to money or property ‥ [40.2.10]
Payment into court — enforcement of order for ‥ [40.2.20]
Service — dispensing with where terms of judgment known ‥ [40.7.10]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 1 PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO THE SUPREME COURT ONLY [rr 40.1 –40.4]

leg:heading.title: PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO THE SUPREME COURT ONLY [rr 40.1 –40.4]

p.text: This Division applies to judgments and orders of the Supreme Court (in this Division referred to simply as judgments), and so applies in addition to the provisions of Part 8 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005.
Legislation cited in [40.1.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 106(1).
Section 106(1) of the CPA permits enforcement of money judgments by the issue of a writ for the levy of property, a garnishee order or (in the Supreme and District Courts) a charging order.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 40.2] r 40.2 Payment of money (cf SCR Part 42, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Payment of money (cf SCR Part 42, rule 2)

p.text: A judgment for the payment of money (including a judgment for the payment of money into court) may be enforced by one or more of the following means:
appointment of a receiver of the income of the property of the person bound by the judgment,
sequestration of the property of the person bound by the judgment.
Subrule (1) does not affect any other means for enforcement of a judgment for the payment of money.
Legislation cited in [40.2.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 106(2).

A judgment or order for the payment of money may be enforced by any of the means set out in s 106(2) of the CPA and, in the case of Supreme Court judgments, the present r 40.2. These are cumulative, not alternative, remedies. Different kinds of writs of execution may be issued at the same time although they cannot all be acted upon simultaneously: Foster v Jackson (1615) Hob 52; Re Broughton (1916) 17 SR (NSW) 29 . Enforcement of an order under the present rule does not confer any additional substantive rights on the parties in whose favour the original order was made: Abigroup Ltd v Abignano (1992) 39 FCR 74 at 85; 112 ALR 497 ; see Kevern v Marshall [2004] NSWSC 300; BC200401867 .

level.toc-caption: [40.2.10] Judgment altering entitlement to money or property

p.text: Legislation cited in [40.2.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Family Provision Act 1982.

heading.title: Judgment altering entitlement to money or property

p.text: An order altering a trust or estate entitlement (such as an order under the Family Provision Act 1982 , now the Succession Act 2006) is not an order for the payment of money. The proper course to enforce such an order is by proceedings for administration of the estate: Re Jennery [1967] Ch 280; [1967] 2 WLR 201 . (Similarly the common law form of judgment — that the successful party “recover”the judgment amount — was not regarded as a judgment for the payment of money and could not be enforced by committal or by sequestration, nor by a supplementary order fixing a time for payment: Re Oddy [1906] 1 Ch 93 ; Hulbert v Cathcart [1894] 1 QB 244 .)

An order to pay a specific sum is clearly a money judgment, even where the amount has been fixed after a prior order or undertaking imposed — a liability to pay an amount whose quantification depended on later events — such as a liability to pay a “deficiency” ïn the proceeds of sale: Buckley v Crawford [1893] 1 QB 105 . An order to pay a specific sum for costs, or security for costs, is also an order for the payment of money: Jones v Jones [1912] P 295. An mere undertaking to pay money is not a judgment or order and does not come under the rule: Spindler v Balog (1959) 76 WN (NSW) 391 . Neither is an order for specific performance an order for the payment of money.

level.toc-caption: [40.2.20] Payment into court — enforcement of order for

p.text: Legislation cited in [40.2.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 106(2).

heading.title: Payment into court — enforcement of order for

p.text: An order for payment into court is not a judgment for the payment of money to any person, and is not enforceable by the ordinary modes of execution: Re Greer; Napper v Fanshawe [1895] 2 Ch 217 . Such a judgment may be enforced under the present rule but, despite the saving provision contained in r 40.2(2), it is not specifically enforceable by the means referred to in s 106(2) of the CPA. Consequently, an order for payment into court cannot be enforced by a writ of levy of property: Browne v Browne (1925) 42 WN (NSW) 80 ; or by garnishee proceedings: Re Greer; Napper v Fanshawe, above; Nelson v MacDonald [1936] VLR 233 . In Lady de La Pole v Dick (1885) 29 Ch D 351 an order for payment into court was varied on appeal by directing payment to the plaintiff so that the order might be more readily enforced.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 40.3] r 40.3 Leave for issue: sequestration (cf SCR Part 44, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Leave for issue: sequestration (cf SCR Part 44, rule 3)

p.text: A writ of sequestration may not be issued except by leave of the court.
An applicant for leave under this rule:
must file notice of motion, and
must serve the notice, and any affidavit in support of the motion, personally on the person whose property is sought to be sequestrated.
The court may dispense with service under subrule (2)(b).
Legislation cited in [40.3.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.5, r 40.6.

An order for sequestration can be made where a judgment requires money to be paid or where a person is obliged to comply with another form of judgment either forthwith or within a specific time: see r 40.6 of the UCPR. (Despite the power to fix times for compliance under r 36.5 of the UCPR, frequently no such time will be specified in the judgment nor will a time be fixed unless there is a wilful refusal or neglect to comply with the judgment.) For instances where the writ has issued, see Knill v Dumergue [1911] 2 Ch 199 (a vendor’s action for specific performance); Re Slade; Slade v Hulme (1881) 18 Ch D 653 (damages and costs); Willcock v Terrell (1878) 3 Ex D 323 (an order to pay by instalments). The writ had particular application as a means of enforcing judgments against corporations: Worthington v Ad-Lib Club Ltd [1965] Ch 236; [1964] 3 All ER 674 .

An order for sequestration ought not be imposed as a sanction for merely unintentional or accidental: failure to comply with a judgment or order: Fairclough & Sons v Manchester Ship Canal Co (No 2) [1897] WN 7 ; Meters Ltd v Metropolitan Gas Meters Ltd (1907) 51 Sol Jo 499; Stancomb v Trowbridge Urban District Council [1910] 2 Ch 190 . Nor is it appropriate to make the order where the person has complied with the judgment or order since the application was made Inland Revenue Cmrs v Hoogstraten [1984] 3 All ER 25 . However the applicant for the order need not be able to point to any particular property that can be taken under the order: Hulbert v Cathcart [1896] AC 470 . The court may impose a fine in lieu of sequestration especially where sequestration would adversely affect third parties: Steiner Products Ltd v Willy Steiner Ltd [1966] 2 All ER 387; [1966] 1 WLR 986 .

level.toc-caption: [40.3.15] Effect of the writ of sequestration

heading.title: Effect of the writ of sequestration

p.text: The purpose of sequestration is to compel obedience to the order of the court: Australian Consolidated Press Ltd v Morgan (1965) 112 CLR 483 at 498; [1966] ALR 387; BC6500220 . A writ of sequestration involves several persons, nominated by the applicant and consenting to act, being appointed by the court to get in the property of the judgment debtor and retain it or its proceeds until the court’s order is obeyed and the order for sequestration discharged. The sequestrators need not be professional persons and they are not required to give security for what they may receive. (For the general form of the writ, see Miller and Horsell, Equity Forms and Precedents, 1934, p 210) A writ of sequestration issues against the estate of the debtor in rem and is distinct from the process of contempt which is merely personal. The writ binds the real property (Dixon v Rowe (1876) 35 LT 548) and the tangible personal property of the debtor (Burdett v Rockley (1682) 1 Vern 58) of the debtor from the date of its issue. A chose in action is not bound until the sequestrators take some step to assert the right to it: Bucknell v Bucknell [1969] 2 All ER 998; [1969] 1 WLR 1204 ; Re Hoare; Ex parte Nelson (1880) 14 Ch D 41 ; Re Slade; Slade v Hulme (1881) 18 Ch D 653 . The possession of the sequestrators is that of the court and any unauthorised interference with that possession constitutes a contempt: Eckman v Midland Bank Ltd [1973] QB 519; [1973] 2 WLR 284 ; Ward v Booth (1872) LR 14 Eq 195; Angel v Smith (1804) 9 Ves 335; Johnes v Claughton (1822) Jac 572. Property seized under the writ does not become the property of the other party: Re Pollard; Ex parte Pollard [1903] 2 KB 41 . Nor can sequestrators sell the property unless authorised by the court to do so, for example, in order to pay the costs of sequestration: Desbrow v Crominie (1729) 1 Barn KB 212 ; Goldsmith v Goldsmith (1846) 5 Hare 123. The sequestrators may apply to the court for directions as to the management of the property while it is in their possession: Neale v Bealing (1744) 3 Swans 304; 36 ER 874; Cowper v Taylor (1848) 16 Sim 314; Shaw v Wright (1795) 3 Ves 22; 30 ER 872. Sequestrators may be liable to third parties for damages in respect of any dealings with property which comes into their hands: Inland Revenue Cmrs v Hoogstraten [1985] 1 QB 1077. Unless sequestration has issued to compel the performance of a public duty it determines upon the death of the person whose property has bein seized: Pratt v Inman (1889) 43 Ch D 175; [1886–90] All ER Rep Ext 1030 ; Burdett v Rockley (1682) 1 Vern 58.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 40.4] r 40.4 Security for future conduct (cf SCR Part 53, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Security for future conduct (cf SCR Part 53, rule 6)

p.text: If, for the purpose of security for future conduct, the court:
requires any person to pay money into court or otherwise to deposit money, or
puts any person on terms of payment into court or other deposit of money, or
puts any person on terms of procuring payment into court or other deposit of money by some other person,
the court must, by order, specify the circumstances in which the money so paid or deposited is to be forfeited, returned or otherwise disposed of.
If, for the purpose of security for future conduct, the court:
requires any person to submit to an order for the payment of money, or
puts any person on terms of submitting to an order for the payment of money, or

puts any person on terms of procuring some other person to submit to an order for the payment of money, the court must, by order, specify the circumstances in which the order for the payment of money may be made and may, by order, specify the manner in which the submission is to be made.
